W tym miejscu modlitwy bohaterowie otrzymują kolejną wizję, odkrywają nowe właściwości {@item Jewel of Three Prayers|CRCotN} i ponownie stają twarzą w twarz ze swoimi rywalami. Wynik tej konfrontacji nie tylko zadecyduje o tym, kto posiądzie klejnot, ale także określi splątaną sieć relacji między bohaterami, ich rywalami i frakcjami Markizów - tuż przed tym, jak bohaterowie zostaną pochłonięci przez zaklęcie, które przeniesie ich do Marquet.

entries.title: The threshold of the Betrayers' Rise is guarded by soldiers of the Aurora Watch to keep intruders out and demons in

entries.name: Running This Chapter
entries: Pierwsza część tego rozdziału to sekwencja eksploracji, w której bohaterowie wchodzą w interakcje z mieszkańcami i odwiedzają miejsca w Bazzoxan, aby dowiedzieć się więcej o swojej wizji w Szmaragdowej Grocie i {@item Jewel of Three Prayers|CRCotN}. Ta sekcja oraz eksploracja lochów, która po niej następuje, są celowo otwarte i zaprojektowane tak, aby nagrodzić dociekliwe postacie.

Ponieważ bohaterowie mogą udać się w dowolne miejsce w mieście, ważne jest, abyś przeczytał zarówno rozdział "{@area Bazzoxan Overview|0ed|x}", jak i "{@area Locations in Bazzoxan|0f2|x}", aby zapoznać się z miastem przed rozpoczęciem tego rozdziału.

Jeśli bohaterowie utkną lub będą sfrustrowani, możesz użyć przyjaznych postaci spoza gry, takich jak {@creature Verin Thelyss|CRCotN} i agenci frakcji, aby podpowiedzieć im, jak mogą dowiedzieć się więcej. Ostatecznie bohaterowie muszą znaleźć miejsce modlitwy wewnątrz Wzgórza Zdrajców.
Począwszy od tego rozdziału, rywale postaci korzystają z bloków statystyk poziomu 2 (patrz {@adventure appendix A|CRCotN|8}).

entries.name: Who Has the Jewel?
entries: Ścieżkę do miejsca modlitwy można otworzyć tylko za pomocą {@item Jewel of Three Prayers|CRCotN}. Umożliwia to dostęp do fragmentu Wzgórza Zdrajców, który nigdy nie był eksplorowany przez Straż Zorza. Jeśli bohaterowie nie mają klejnotu, mogą być zmuszeni do odebrania go rywalom - ukradkiem, siłą lub w drodze wymiany - jak opisano w {@area area B7|116|x}, w dalszej części rozdziału.

Co więcej, ostateczna konfrontacja w tym rozdziale to pojedynek o posiadanie klejnotu. Niezależnie od tego, czy to rywale, czy bohaterowie zdobędą klejnot, przygoda będzie kontynuowana na odległym kontynencie Marquet. W części "{@area Next Steps|171|x}" rozdziału wyjaśniono, jak przenieść bohaterów z Bazzoxan do nowej lokacji.

entries.name: No Time for Pleasantries
entries: Ten rozdział rozpoczyna się, gdy dwóch Strażników Aurory {@creature Guard||guards} prowadzi bohaterów od bramy Bazzoxan w kierunku Koszar Gatehold. Przeczytaj lub sparafrazuj poniższe fragmenty, gdy bohaterowie wejdą do miasta:

Zza rogu rozpadającego się budynku wyłania się pięć drgających, pozbawionych skóry mas o mrugających oczach i rozdziawionych paszczach. Jedna z nich w trzech swoich amorficznych paszczach rozdrabnia ciało nieszczęsnego żołnierza. Trąbki ogłaszają alarm, a kilku żołnierzy Straży Zorza pospiesznie wkracza na ulice. Jeden z nich, drow płci męskiej, zatrzymuje się, by zwrócić się do ciebie. "Nowo przybyli? Nie czas na uprzejmości. Wyciągnijcie broń lub uciekajcie w bezpieczne miejsce! Znajdźcie mnie potem w koszarach!".

entries.title: A gibbering mouther threatens two Aurora Watch soldiers

entries: Pięciu {@creature Gibbering Mouther||gibbering mouthers} zakradło się do Bazzoxan i zamierza pożreć każdego, kto stanie im na drodze. Ich przeciwnikami są członkowie Straży Zorzy pod wodzą Taskhanda {@creature Verin Thelyss|CRCotN} (patrz załączony blok statystyk).

Dla mieszkańców Bazzoxan Verin jest promykiem nadziei pośród ciemności, które spowijają miasto. Jednak ciężar odpowiedzialności sprawia, że pogodne i młodzieńcze usposobienie Verina nabiera melancholii. Zależy mu na mieście, które przysiągł chronić, ale jest zmęczony nieustannym zagrożeniem ze strony mieszkańców Wzgórza Zdrajców.

Sygnały alarmowe z wież strażniczych w całym mieście wskazują, że podobne ataki mają miejsce w innych miejscach. Cywile udają się do bezpiecznych budynków, podczas gdy członkowie Straży Aurory mobilizują się, by stawić czoła zagrożeniu. Po wyrazie twarzy i wyćwiczonych ruchach bohaterów można wywnioskować, że takie ataki zdarzają się często. Bohaterowie mogą albo zaangażować się w walkę, albo uciekać w bezpieczne miejsce.

entries.title: {@creature Verin Thelyss|CRCotN}

entries.name: Fight!
entries: Jeśli postacie zdecydują się pomóc Aurorskiej Straży, wszyscy toczą inicjatywę. {@creature Verin Thelyss|CRCotN|Verin} i dwóch orków {@creature Guard||guards} z Aurorskiej Straży zostaje z partią, podczas gdy reszta żołnierzy odchodzi, aby zabezpieczyć inne części miasta.

entries.name: Rivals
entries: Jeśli rywale towarzyszą bohaterom w momencie wejścia do Bazzoxan, Verin kieruje ich do pomocy w obronie ambulatorium ({@area area B3|0fe|x}). Są chwilowo oburzeni, że im się rozkazuje, ale ustawiają się w szeregu, kiedy Ayo powtarza polecenie.

entries.name: Flight!
entries: Jeśli bohaterowie uciekają, muszą znaleźć bezpieczny budynek, w którym będą mogli się ukryć. Szybko okazuje się, że większość takich miejsc została już zabarykadowana przez zamkniętych w nich mieszkańców. Postać, która chce dostać się do jednego z takich bezpiecznych domów, musi zdać test Charyzmy DC 20 ({@skill Persuasion}), aby przekonać jego mieszkańców do otwarcia drzwi. Alternatywnie, postać może wykonać test Mądrości ({@skill Perception}) DC 20, aby przeskanować okolicę i znaleźć dostępną skrytkę. Postać może wykonać jeden z tych testów raz na minutę. Za każdym razem, gdy postać nie zda jednego z tych testów, {@creature gibbering mouther} wyłania się z ukrycia i atakuje ją.

entries.name: Rivals
entries: Jeśli rywale są z bohaterami, gdy ci wkraczają do Bazzoxan, Verin rozkazuje im zostać i walczyć, podczas gdy bohaterowie uciekają. Ayo Jabe nie lubi przyjmować rozkazów, ale podporządkowuje się - podobnie jak jej towarzysze.

entries.name: Aftermath
entries: Alarmy ucichają po 5 minutach, sygnalizując, że niebezpieczeństwo zostało zażegnane. W Bazzoxan znów zapanował niespokojny spokój codziennego życia. Potwory, które zaatakowały inne części miasta, zostały rozprawione przez żołnierzy Straży Aurory.

Po pokonaniu bełkoczących paszczaków żołnierze Straży Aurory zaczynają przenosić rannych do ambulatorium ({@area area B3|0fe|x}). W ten czy inny sposób rywale trafiają po bitwie do ambulatorium, a ich stan zależy od działań bohaterów:

items: Jeśli bohaterowie walczyli u boku Verina, rywale są bezpieczni w ambulatorium i z niecierpliwością czekają na wieści.

Jeśli bohaterowie uciekli z cywilami, zostawiając rywali, by walczyli u boku Verina, Ayo Jabe została ciężko ranna w bitwie. Maggie Keeneyes zaniosła Ayo do ambulatorium, gdzie opatrzył ją Dermot Wurder. Irvan i Galsariad stoją przed ambulatorium, martwiąc się o przyszłość swojej grupy.

entries.name: Chatting with Verin
entries: Jeśli bohaterowie są z Verinem w momencie zakończenia bitwy, przedstawi się on oficjalnie jako przywódca Bazzoxan i przeprosi, że ich przybycie zostało utrudnione przez atak bełkoczącej mordki. Odpowiada na ogólne pytania dotyczące Bazzoxan (wszystko to, co znajdziesz w sekcji "Przegląd Bazzoxan" poniżej), ale wkrótce wymiguje się, aby sprawdzić, co z resztą miasta. Pozostawia bohaterom możliwość zbadania Bazzoxan w wolnej chwili i zaprasza ich do spotkania się z nim później w Koszarach Gatehold ({@area area B4|104|x}).

entries.name: Bazzoxan Overview
entries: Bazzoxan tętni życiem. Ludzie sprzątają gruzy po ostatnim ataku, opiekują się rannymi, odprawiają ostatnie rytuały za zmarłych, naprawiają fortyfikacje i przygotowują się do kolejnego najazdu. Bełkoczące mordki - stworzone przez demony z okresu Powstania Zdrajców - są częstym zagrożeniem, podobnie jak nędznicy, quasici i inne pomniejsze demony. W rzadkich przypadkach atakują potężniejsze demony lub demoniczna energia ożywia ciała martwych żołnierzy Straży Zorza.

Większość mieszkańców miasta to żołnierze, którzy rozumieją, że ich zadaniem nie jest pokonanie okropieństw w Powstaniu Zdrajców, ale utrzymanie ich w ryzach tak długo, jak to możliwe. Cywilni mieszkańcy miasta żyją tak normalnie, jak to tylko możliwe, i niewielu narzeka na swoją sytuację.
Szczegółowe informacje na temat miejsc w mieście można znaleźć w części "{@area Locations in Bazzoxan|0f2|x}" w dalszej części rozdziału.

entries.title: Bazzoxan has an eerie beauty that is lost on most visitors and residents

entries.name: Geography
entries: Bazzoxan leży u podnóża rdzawoczerwonego masywu górskiego na północ od doliny znanej jako Barbed Fields. Skalisty, skalisty krajobraz jest w większości pozbawiony roślinności, poza kilkoma kruchymi sosnami i pasmami zarośli.

Bazzoxan było niegdyś dobrze prosperującym miastem górniczym, ale zostało zniszczone, gdy odkrywcy odkryli portal do Otchłani w głębinach Wzlotu Zdrajców. Wiele budynków w mieście zostało zniszczonych podczas pierwszego ataku demonów, a miasto zostało pospiesznie przekształcone w placówkę wojskową, aby utrzymać demony w ryzach. Jedynymi regularnie remontowanymi obiektami są koszary Straży Aurory, z których większość to budynki przerobione niezgodnie z ich pierwotnym przeznaczeniem.

entries.name: Sacrifice Engines
entries: Jednym z najbardziej charakterystycznych elementów Bazzoxan są dwa silniki ofiarne, z których każdy to głęboki na 30 stóp dół wyłożony rzędami srebrnych ostrzy. Ostrza można wprawić w ruch obrotowy, pociągając za dźwignię znajdującą się przy krawędzi szybu. Istota znajdująca się w jamie, gdy ostrza się obracają, otrzymuje 44 ({@dice 8d10}) obrażeń od cięcia na początku każdej swojej tury.

W dawnych czasach słudzy Bogów Zdrajców wrzucali do tych dołów śmiertelników, aby ułagodzić swoich złych panów. Obecnie Straż Aurory wrzuca do nich demony i inne potwory, aby uniknąć długotrwałych walk.

entries.name: Populace
entries: Większość mieszkańców Bazzoxan to członkowie Straży Aurory. Przebywa tu również garstka arkanistów z dynastii Kryn, którzy próbują odnaleźć i zapieczętować szczeliny planarne zagrażające miastu. Radzenie sobie z tymi zjawiskami wykracza poza obecne możliwości bohaterów, a w każdym razie nie mogą oni pozwolić sobie na pozostanie w Bazzoxan, aby ich rywale nie znaleźli miejsca modlitwy Avandry przed nimi. Niemniej jednak, ten rozdział stanowi okazję do tego, aby zapowiedzieć zniszczenia, jakie szczelina do Netherdeep może spowodować w Ank'Harel w dalszej części przygody.

Nieliczni cywile, którzy pozostali w Bazzoxan, wspierają żołnierzy najlepiej, jak potrafią, i są szkoleni w podstawach walki na wypadek, gdyby siły z Powstania Zdrajców zaczęły przeważać nad wojskiem. Większość mieszkańców to drowi, ale mieszkają tu także gobliny, hobgobliny, bugbears, orkowie i inne ludy Xhorhasian.

Większość mieszkańców Bazzoxan unika rozmowy, powołując się na konieczność wypełnienia swoich obowiązków, jeśli ktoś się do nich zbliży. Tabela Sceny w Bazzoxan zawiera propozycje drobnych spotkań, których bohaterowie mogą doświadczyć podczas zwiedzania miasta.

entries.caption: Bazzoxan Scenes
rows: Chaotyczny neutralny ork {@creature berserker} pielęgnuje ogródek z warzywami korzennymi w jednym ze zrujnowanych budynków, agresywnie wyrywając chwasty.
Zmęczona matka drowów (neutralnie dobra {@creature commoner}) siedzi na rynku i instruuje swoje dzieci, co mają robić, gdy ona umrze.
Zmęczony kupiec drowów (neutralny {@creature commoner}) próbuje sprzedać to, co zostało z jego zapasów.
Żołnierz Straży Aurory (praworządny dobry {@creature drow elite warrior}) przerywa bójkę między dwoma szlochającymi obywatelami (praworządny dobry {@creature Commoner||commoners}).
Dziesięciu Strażników Aurory {@creature Guard||guards} (praworządni dobrzy drowowie, ludzie i orkowie) biegnie w szyku, utrzymując tempo śpiewając o tym, jak zginą.
Neutralny dobry {@creature bugbear} naprawia wózek inwalidzki praworządnego neutralnego drow'a {@creature veteran}, który stracił nogę.
Nastoletni, praworządny, neutralny krasnolud {@creature acolyte} siedzi w ciemnym kącie i płacze, trzymając hełm na piersi.
Człowiek o czerwonej twarzy (chaotyczny neutralny {@creature commoner}) bredzi po pijanemu o tym, że demony nadchodzą, aby ich wszystkich zabić.
Dwóch członków Straży Aurory, praworządny neutralny {@creature drow elite warrior} i chaotyczny neutralny {@creature ogre}, kłóci się o to, który z nich powinien podjąć się niebezpiecznego zadania.
Stary tiefling (praworządny dobry {@creature veteran}) szlocha, niosąc małą trumnę w stronę krematorium ({@area area B2|0f4|x}).

entries.name: Rivals in Bazzoxan
entries: Po spotkaniu z bełkoczącymi pyskaczami rywale tracą nieco ze swojej wesołości. Choć starają się zachowywać pozory, są mocno wstrząśnięci tym doświadczeniem. Najbardziej dotknięty jest Galsariad, którego sarkastyczne zachowanie staje się niemal obraźliwe zarówno wobec przyjaciół, jak i przeciwników, ponieważ jego niepewność siebie zaczyna wychodzić na wierzch. Irvan staje się wycofany, przytłoczony opresyjną atmosferą Bazzoxan i chorobliwym humorem miejscowych. Dermot żarliwie oddaje się przestrzeganiu zasad Luxonu, zdecydowany zrobić wszystko, by chronić swoich przyjaciół i rzadko opuszcza stronę Ayo. Jeśli uda się go namówić na chwilę oderwania od grupy, otwarcie mówi o swoich obawach. Zdaje sobie sprawę, że jego przyjaciele przeżyli traumę i chciałby, aby wrócili do domu, a nie kontynuowali działania. Bez względu na wszystko, zamierza wspierać ich do końca.

Jeśli Ayo została ranna podczas spotkania w wyniku decyzji bohaterów o ucieczce i ukryciu się, rywale są wrogo nastawieni do tego, kogo postrzegają jako przywódcę bohaterów, a Maggie Keeneyes jest wrogo nastawiona do całej grupy z powodu ich tchórzostwa. Ayo jest wstrząśnięta obrażeniami, przez co zaczyna wątpić w swoje umiejętności przywódcze, ale nie żywi złej woli wobec bohaterów, którzy postawili swoje bezpieczeństwo na pierwszym miejscu.

entries.name: Locations in Bazzoxan
entries: Poniższe lokalizacje są przypisane do mapy Bazzoxan.

entries.name: B1: Gate of Bazzoxan
entries: Wejście do Bazzoxan stanowi szeroka brama, którą otwiera się i zamyka ze szczytu murów obronnych za pomocą szeregu kół, łańcuchów i kół pasowych.

entries.name: B2: Crematorium
entries: Krematorium jest prostym, kamiennym budynkiem wzniesionym na zboczu góry.
Gdy bohaterowie zbliżą się do budynku, przeczytaj lub sparafrazuj poniższe zdanie:
Z kominów tego kamiennego budynku unosi się gęsty, cierpki dym. Na małym podwórku na północny wschód od budynku leżą zwłoki zawinięte w beżowe płótno.

Niewysoki mężczyzna w skórzanym fartuchu wita Cię przy wejściu z zaskakującą radością. "Widzę, że nowe ciała dla Bazzoxan!". Za nim stoi olbrzymi mężczyzna: muskularny, niebieskooki, z krótko ściętymi włosami i brakiem ręki.

Ci dwaj mężczyźni to Reynard Allerton, chaotyczny dobry {@creature scout}, i jego większy, starszy brat Sebastian Allerton, neutralny dobry {@creature thug}. Ich krematorium posiada dwa piece, z których każdy może pomieścić do czterech ciał średnich lub jednego dużego. Bracia są odpowiedzialni za właściwą utylizację zwłok. Reynard wydaje się być bardziej towarzyski z rodzeństwa, choć jeśli bohaterowie potrafią wydobyć Sebastiana z ciszy żartem lub miłą uwagą, starszy brat okazuje się być także dobrodusznym gadułą.
Kiedy bohaterowie przybywają na miejsce, bracia palą właśnie ostatnią partię zwłok. Reynard natychmiast prosi bohaterów, by pomogli jemu i jego bratu w wykonaniu zadania.

entries.name: Corpse Disposal
entries: W miarę jak bracia (oraz postacie, które zdecydują się im pomóc) przeczesują stos ciał, Reynard staje się coraz bardziej niechętny do kontynuowania pracy, prosząc bohaterów o zajęcie się ciałami i wymyślając wymówki, dlaczego powinien zająć się ogniem. Postać, której powiedzie się test Mądrości DC 11 ({@skill Insight}), może stwierdzić, że Reynard celowo unika jednego z dużych ciał znajdujących się na samym dole stosu, z pogardy i przerażenia.

Postacie, które pomagają przy stosie ciał, znajdują źródło obrzydzenia Reynarda: martwego vrocka, którego ciało cuchnie podrobami i krwią. Reynard odkłada zadanie spalenia go, ponieważ uważa demona za odrażającego, a także dlatego, że zwłoki nie rozpuściły się w kałuży demonicznej ichoru, tak jak powinny, co sugeruje jakąś nieprawidłowość.
Zanim ktokolwiek zdążył pozbyć się szczątków vrocka, w pobliżu powstało zamieszanie:

"Zaczekaj! Stój!" - krzyczy głos z głębi ulicy. W oddali pojawia się książkowy tiefling. U jego pasa wiszą różne narzędzia archeologiczne, a w torbie trzyma swoje notatniki. "Nie możesz tego jeszcze spalić. Muszę to zbadać!". Sięgając do torby, wyciąga odznakę i trzyma ją w górze, tak jakby sama odznaka wyjaśniała powód, dla którego tu jest.

Tiefling jest {@creature Prolix Yusaf|CRCotN}, praworządnym neutralnym {@creature scholarly agent|CRCotN} (patrz {@adventure appendix A|CRCotN|8}) wyznawcą Alegionu Wszechwidzenia. Na jego odznace widnieje symbol jego frakcji: zwój z pojedynczym, czujnym okiem.

Prolix przedstawia się jako archeolog z Ank'Harel, miasta na odległym kontynencie Marquet. Nerwowo wyjaśnia, że ponieważ vrocki często połykają biżuterię i inne ozdobne przedmioty, ma powody sądzić, że vrock może mieć w żołądku kilka cennych przedmiotów z Powstania Zdrajców - i chciałby spróbować je wyciąć, zanim Allertonowie spalą zwłoki.

Nie mając doświadczenia z martwymi ciałami, Prolix zwraca się o pomoc do postaci. Postać, która chce wydobyć zawartość żołądka vrocka, musi najpierw przebić się przez jego skórę. Aby to zrobić, postać musi zdać test Mądrości DC 15 ({@skill Survival}). Nieudany test wywołuje erupcję zarodników ze zwłok vrocka, które wypełniają kulę o promieniu 10 stóp od zwłok. Wszystkie istoty w tym obszarze muszą wykonać rzut na przetrwanie przed utratą Konstytucji DC 14 lub staną się {@condition poisoned}. Stworzenie {@condition poisoned} w ten sposób otrzymuje 5 ({@dice 1d10}) obrażeń od trucizny na początku każdej swojej tury. Może powtórzyć rzut ratujący na koniec każdej swojej tury, kończąc efekt na sobie w przypadku sukcesu.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: W przełyku vrock'a znajduje się para złotych {@item eyes of the eagle}, trzy krzykliwe pierścienie warte 2 gp każdy oraz pudełko w kształcie sześcianu wykonane z onyksu i mierzące 3 cale z boku. Zaklęcie {@spell detect magic} ujawnia aurę magii ablucji wokół pudełka, które jest zamknięte. Prolix chwyta je, zanim zrobi to ktokolwiek inny, pozostawiając pozostałe przedmioty bohaterom. Gdy tylko pudełko z zagadkami zostanie wyjęte z przełyku martwego vrocka, czar na vrocku znika, a on sam zaczyna się rozpuszczać w kałuży cuchnącej ichoru.

Każdy, kto przez 1 minutę będzie majstrował przy mechanizmie zamykającym pudełko, może wykonać test Inteligencji DC 20 i otworzyć pudełko, jeśli mu się powiedzie. Pudełko zawiera zwiniętą {@item spell scroll} z {@spell bestow curse}.

entries.title: {@creature Aloysia Telfan|CRCotN} and {@creature Prolix Yusaf|CRCotN}

entries.name: Roleplaying Prolix
entries: Po zdobyciu pudełka z zagadkami zachowanie Prolixa zmienia się z przyjaznego na powściągliwe. Twierdzi, że wie, jak odblokować pudełko, ale nalega, aby zrobić to w odosobnionym miejscu, aby "niebezpieczeństwo" w nim zawarte nikogo nie skrzywdziło. Postać, której powiedzie się test Mądrości DC 10 ({@skill Insight}), może stwierdzić, że Prolix kłamie i stara się brzmieć jak ktoś ważny.

Postać, która prosi Prolixa o odpowiedź, może wykonać test Charyzmy DC 12 ({@skill Persuasion}). Jeśli test się powiedzie, Prolix udziela jednej z poniższych odpowiedzi; jeśli wynik testu wyniesie 5 lub więcej, staje się przyjazny dla postaci i swobodnie dzieli się wszystkim, co wie:

entries.name: Why are you here
entries: "Jestem archeologiem, ale nie przyszedłem tu, aby zajmować się archeologią jako taką. Zostałem wysłany przez Alegiancję Wszechwidzenia, aby szpiegować konkurencyjnego agenta Konsorcjum Śnienia". Prolix mówi, że Alegiacja nie wie, dlaczego Konsorcjum wysłało kogoś do Bazzoxan, ale powód nie może być dobry.

entries.name: Who is your rival
entries: "Alojzja. Tak ma na imię. Szuka czegoś w Powstaniu Zdrajców. Nietrudno ją zauważyć. Wysoka, blada, ubrana na czerwono. Zimnokrwista. Wygląda na to, że zrobi wszystko, by dostać to, czego chce. A to, czego chce, to... no cóż, właśnie tego chciałbym się dowiedzieć!". Prolix mówi dalej, że zarówno on, jak i Aloysia zatrzymali się w Pokoju Gotów ({@area area R7|142|x}).

entries.name: Do you know how to open the puzzle box or not
entries: "Oczywiście, że nie! Ale pochodzi z wnętrza świątyni - musi zawierać coś ważnego". Prolix zamierza nie dopuścić, aby skrzynia i jej zawartość wpadły w ręce Alojzego.

Jeśli bohaterowie pozwolą Prolixowi zatrzymać pudełko z zagadkami, zaproponuje im układ: jeśli dowiedzą się, co kombinuje Aloysia i powstrzymają ją, da im 200 gp, a także pudełko i wszystko, co może się w nim znajdować.

entries.name: Prolix and the Jewel
entries: Jeśli postacie mają {@item Jewel of Three Prayers|CRCotN} i pokażą go Prolixowi, ten powie, że nie wie, co przedstawia ten klejnot, choć rozpoznaje go jako coś potężnego i starożytnego. Jeśli bohaterowie dadzą mu szansę, narysuje szybki szkic przedmiotu, zrobi kilka notatek i zaprosi bohaterów, aby wrócili z nim do Kryształowego Zamku, jego uniwersytetu w Ank'Harel, po zakończeniu ich misji w Bazzoxan. Sugeruje, że w bibliotekach uniwersytetu można znaleźć więcej informacji na temat przeznaczenia klejnotu.

Jeśli bohaterowie wydają się chętni, by dowiedzieć się czegoś więcej o klejnocie, Prolix wspomina o spotkaniu z "prawdziwym bystrzakiem", który również zatrzymał się w Komnacie Gotów ({@area area B7|116|x}). Tym innym uczonym jest tiefling o imieniu Question, który, jak sądzi Prolix, również odwiedza Bazzoxan w celach badawczych. Prolix wspomina, że poprzedniej nocy prowadził z Pytonem ożywioną dyskusję na temat najważniejszych postaci historycznych Kalamitów.

entries.name: B3: Infirmary
entries: Trzy budynki na obrzeżach centralnego placu mają drzwi oznaczone symbolem ręki rozżarzonej magią, co oznacza, że są to miejsca uzdrawiania. Kiedy bohaterowie wejdą do jednego z budynków, przeczytaj lub sparafrazuj poniższe zdanie:

Ściany wyłożone są półkami, na których leżą stare książki i materiały medyczne. Podłoga wypełniona jest wąskimi łóżeczkami. Z tyłu znajduje się małe biuro, którego drzwi są uchylone, a w powietrzu unosi się zapach leczniczych okładów.

W środku bohaterowie znajdują praworządnego, neutralnego drow'a {@creature priest} rozmawiającego z młodą kobietą drow'em, której zbroja i torba Aurora Watch leżą na stosie obok. Inni ranni pacjenci - w większości śpiący - wypełniają łóżka w ambulatorium.

Widząc postacie, kapłanka odchodzi od pacjenta i wita się z nimi, przedstawiając się jako Bautha Dyrr. Następnie pyta ich o zdrowie. Postać, która zda test na Inteligencję DC 15 ({@skill Religion}), rozpoznaje, że przypinka w kształcie czarnego skrzydła przyczepiona do płaszcza Bauthy to święty symbol Xalicasa, legendarnego solariusza, który służył jako prawa ręka Corellona Arcy-Serca, zanim upadł w czasie kataklizmu. Jako wyznawczyni Xalicasa, Bautha nie pochwala działań rekultywacyjnych w Bazzoxan. Chociaż popiera wysiłki mające na celu powstrzymanie sił Otchłani, uważa, że obecność wojsk dynastii Kryn w tym miejscu powoduje niepotrzebne ofiary i niewiele z tego wynika. Mimo to, Bautha stara się leczyć i chronić mieszkańców Bazzoxan, a także rzuca {@spell cure wounds} lub {@spell lesser restoration} na ofiary za darmo, o ile ma wolne sloty na zaklęcia.

Bautha posiada również {@item spell scroll} z {@spell greater restoration}. Aby rzucić zaklęcie ze zwoju, musi jej się udać test Mądrości DC 15; w przeciwnym razie zwój zostanie zniszczony bez efektu. Sprzeda go bohaterom za 500 gp.

Bautha is familiar with {@creature Prolix Yusaf|CRCotN} and {@creature Aloysia Telfan|CRCotN}, since both individuals have visited the infirmary for care in the past week. She sees them as reckless and naive, and she thinks that their obsession with researching the Betrayers' Rise can lead to no good end. A character who succeeds on a DC 13 Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) check gets her to reveal that Aloysia was injured when she tried to delve into the Betrayers' Rise alone—and now she's looking for mercenaries to explore it on her behalf.

entries.name: Bautha and the Jewel
entries: If the characters show Bautha the {@item Jewel of Three Prayers|CRCotN}, identify it by name, and ask her about it, she doesn't recognize it, but something about the name reminds her of an old tale. She thinks for a moment, then says:

"Three prayers... Oh! You know, it must be that old story about the champion of three gods. Goodness gracious, I can't believe I remembered it. It's a fragment of a fragment of a legend, even in temples in Vasselheim and Ank'Harel." She clears her throat. "Long ago, a hero of the Calamity begged for aid from three different gods in his time of need. Avandra the Change Bringer was one of them, and I think Sehanine the Moon Weaver was another. And, uh, I'm afraid I don't remember anything else."
As the characters prepare to leave the infirmary, Bautha suddenly recalls one other detail:

"This might be a fiction, but Avandra is said to have grieved for the hero—not because he had died, but because she feared her aid forced him to give up so much of himself that he would be robbed of a future."

entries.name: Naevyn's Request
entries: As the characters make their way to the exit, the wounded member of the Aurora Watch calls for the characters to approach her cot. Her body is covered with wounds she received in the gibbering mouther attack.

The drow is Naevyn Tasithar, a neutral good {@creature scout}. She weakly salutes the characters, then asks them to hand her her satchel. She pulls out a small tiger's eye carving of a rabbit with her name carved into the bottom. Naevyn explains that she was planning to visit the Wall of the Unforgotten ({@area area B6|114|x}) and place this trinket there. If asked why, she looks away and refuses to answer, but asks the characters to place it by the wall. Characters who speak to Kalym, a priest stationed at the wall, can learn Naevyn's reason.

entries.name: B4: Gatehold Barracks
entries: The Aurora Watch's command center is located in the Gatehold Barracks. The complex contains lodgings for Taskhand {@creature Verin Thelyss|CRCotN} and his senior officers, as well as accommodations for regular soldiers. Like most of Bazzoxan's buildings, these are in a constant state of reconstruction; splintered boards and broken shingles are salvaged to be sorted and repurposed, and canvas is tacked up on walls to cover holes that have yet to be repaired.
When the characters enter this area for the first time, read or paraphrase the following:
These barracks are filled with the sounds of chatter, voices shouting orders, and clanging metal. Armored Aurora Watch soldiers go about their business, performing drills and sharpening weapons.

The barracks are divided into four main sections: the war room, the mess hall, the training area, and the sleeping quarters. If Taskhand {@creature Verin Thelyss|CRCotN} is expecting the characters, a soldier is waiting for them and leads them to the war room.

entries.name: War Room
entries: The war room is a small, sparsely furnished office Verin uses to discuss battle strategy and political concerns with his officers. A circular table in the center of the room is covered with maps of Bazzoxan; updated barricade designs; and notes regarding various horrid creatures, their redoubts, and the rifts they spawn from.
Verin greets the characters with warmth and gentle concern. After the initial pleasantries, he politely asks the characters to state their intended business in Bazzoxan.
As the conversation unfolds, Verin shares the following information:

items: An expedition from the Library of the Cobalt Soul is currently in the Betrayers' Rise with an Aurora Watch escort, researching battles of the Calamity that took place within its halls.

An agent of a foreign organization calling itself the Consortium of the Vermilion Dream is staying in Bazzoxan. This agent, an elf named Aloysia, has been reprimanded for trying to bribe Aurora Watch soldiers to protect her while she searches for an ancient holy site she claims is within the Betrayers' Rise.

An archaeologist named Prolix from the Allegiance of Allsight in Ank'Harel also recently arrived in Bazzoxan. He is ostensibly assisting Aurora Watch arcanists who are researching ways to seal the rift within the Betrayers' Rise. Verin suspects that the archaeologist has other motives, because he was seen earlier in the day lurking around the crematorium ({@area area B2|0f4|x}).

entries: If the characters ask Verin to share his thoughts regarding Bazzoxan's connection to the Calamity, he dissembles. A character who presses Verin for more information can make a DC 14 Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) check. If the check succeeds, Verin admits he believes the Betrayers' Rise might hold the solution to breaking the stalemate that grips the town, and he has sent out scouting parties and arcane experts to confirm that idea. None of the expeditions have been fruitful so far, and Verin can't spare any more personnel to expand the effort.

If the characters tell Verin that they intend to journey to the Betrayers' Rise, he asks them to proceed with caution—and to retreat if they think they're getting in over their heads, since he can't afford to send soldiers to help them. He explains:

"The Betrayers' Rise is... challenging to navigate. Its passages shift to confuse mapmakers and search parties. I think the power of the Abyss flows through it, warping the environment so no two groups follow the same path through it. Whether it's demon magic or not doesn't really matter; all I know is that if you get lost down there, my soldiers won't be able to find you."

entries.name: Mess Hall
entries: The mess hall, on the west side of the area, is filled with tables and plain wooden chairs. Though it's meant to be for soldiers, food here is doled out to anyone who asks. The repast consists of gruel, plain vegetables, bread, tough meat, and smoked fish.

The soldiers gathered here are relaxing and sharing gossip about recent events in the town. Characters who loiter in the mess hall overhear the following pieces of information, which they can also learn by engaging any of the soldiers in conversation:

items: One member of the Cobalt Soul expedition, a tiefling named Question, went with his group up to the gate of the Betrayers' Rise but elected not to enter the place. He's holed up at the Ready Room ({@area area B7|116|x}), ready to talk about his research with anyone who will listen.

An elf named Aloysia tried to bribe some soldiers into escorting her into the Betrayers' Rise. Some people believe that she wants only to ransack the temple, but others think her concern is religious and she is searching for long-lost lore about the Prime Deities.

entries.name: Training Area
entries: One of the buildings in the center of the barracks is used as a training area, where new soldiers learn their trade under the watch of officers. The characters can engage with the soldiers in three ways:

items.name: Shooting Match.
items.entry: If a character carries a ranged weapon, a grizzled orc {@creature veteran} challenges that character to a friendly shooting match. The match consists of 3 rounds, during each of which a participant makes one attack with the ranged weapon of their choice at a target 40 feet away. The target has a bullseye surrounded by three concentric rings, each one corresponding to a point value. A hit inside the outer ring (AC 14) is worth 1 point, a hit inside the middle ring (AC 16) is worth 3 points, and a hit inside the inner ring (AC 18) is worth 5 points. A critical hit scores a bullseye, which is worth 10 points. Whoever has the most points at the end of the 3 rounds is the victor (ties are possible).

items.name: Sparring Match.
items.entry: A character can challenge an Aurora Watch soldier, or vice versa, to a sparring match with training weapons. This match can be run as a combat encounter, using the {@creature veteran} stat block for the character's opponent. A creature reduced to 0 hit points by a training weapon falls {@condition unconscious} and is stable. The match ends when one participant falls {@condition unconscious} or concedes defeat.

items.name: Wrestling Match.
items.entry: A character can challenge an Aurora Watch soldier, or vice versa, to a wrestling match. Have a character make three DC 14 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) or Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics}) checks in a row (character's choice of which skill to use). If at least two of these checks succeed, the character's opponent taps out; otherwise, the character loses the match.

entries.name: Sleeping Quarters
entries: The sleeping quarters in the Gatehold Barracks contain small armories where the soldiers can store their weapons and equipment when they're off duty.
The characters aren't permitted in this location, and there is no treasure to be found here.

entries.name: B5: Dilapidated Temple
entries: What was once a flourishing, spiral-shaped temple has fallen into disrepair after those who tended to it were driven away or slain by demons. It has been transformed into an indoor farming plot to grow Xhorhasian vegetables that don't require sunlight.
When the characters enter the area, read or paraphrase the following:

Glass crunches underfoot amid overgrown weeds. Collapsed walls have been replaced with rows of wooden shelves that hold earthenware pots. Numerous alcoves are being used as planters for stubborn flora. Just outside the far end of the enclosure, a smashed mosaic of stained glass sits in a splintered window frame next to a withered, skeletal tree.

A character who makes a successful DC 17 Intelligence ({@skill Religion}) check can piece together that the mosaic once depicted a woman's face on a golden disk: the iconography of Avandra the Change Bringer.

entries.name: Foghome the Gardener
entries: A neutral good, firbolg {@creature priest} named Foghome moves through the temple at all hours of the day. For more information on firbolgs, see the accompanying "Firbolgs of Exandria" sidebar.

entries.title: Foghome the Firbolg

entries: Foghome is here as a guest of Taskhand {@creature Verin Thelyss|CRCotN} because he has offered to help the Aurora Watch create its own food source. Foghome can tell the characters several things:

items: No vegetation survives for long in Bazzoxan. Foghome thinks this is the result of the corrupting influence of the Betrayers' Rise.

He is a follower of Melora the Wild Mother, but he recognizes the temple as a former holy place of Avandra the Change Bringer. He hopes to honor both deities by cultivating new life in the midst of the death and destruction that haunts this place.

While meditating the other night, he felt something surge within the earth nearby—a warm and kindly presence reminiscent of the Prime Deities. He suspects the presence is a sign that a relic of the Calamity has awakened within the Betrayers' Rise.

entries.name: Firbolgs of Exandria
entries: Firbolgs are forest-dwelling Humanoids native to the Greying Wildlands of Wildemount. They are on the tall side of Medium, and their bodies are covered with thick fur ranging in color from tones of brown and ruddy red to cool gray and blue, and occasionally in hues of pink or green. They have floppy, pointed ears and broad, pink noses.
A firbolg nonplayer character encountered in Exandria might have one or both of the following traits:

entries.name: Powerful Build
entries: The firbolg counts as one size larger when determining its carrying capacity and the weight it can push, drag, or lift.

entries.name: Speech of Beast and Leaf
entries: The firbolg can communicate in a limited way with Beasts and Plants. These creatures understand the meaning of the firbolg's words, though the firbolg has no ability to understand their languages. In addition, the firbolg has advantage on Charisma checks it makes to influence a Beast or Plant.

entries.name: Foghome and the Jewel
entries: If asked about the {@item Jewel of Three Prayers|CRCotN}, Foghome has no recollection of an item bearing that name. If he examines the jewel, he correctly senses three fragments of divine power within it, one awake and two slumbering. He also tells the characters that one of the fragments in the jewel is similar to the presence he felt within the earth while he was meditating.

Foghome invites the characters to visit him at the temple any time. He mentions that he meditates to commune with the Wild Mother in the evenings, and he would be happy to reach out to her for more answers on the characters' behalf if they decide to join him one night.
If the characters take him up on his offer, they receive a vision during Foghome's meditation:

You see a young human, curls plastered to his brow by sweat, sinking to his knees in the garden. His eyes betray a lack of sleep, and despite the softness of his features, he looks like he has experienced more pain than any one person should bear. "They're counting on me," he whispers. "They need me, but I'm exhausted and frightened. What do I do? Please. Someone tell me—what do I do?"

The moons race across the sky, soon replaced by the angry red sun that rises before a fateful battle. Five silhouettes approach the temple, and one claps the kneeling figure on the back. Their voices are muffled, as if coming at you through water, but you see them embrace, standing strong, before marching off to war.

When the vision concludes, the characters fall {@condition prone} on the ground, having momentarily passed out. Foghome doesn't see the vision, but he sees the characters fall {@condition unconscious} and then awaken moments later. If they admit to seeing the vision, he asks them to describe it before nodding slowly and explaining he has seen the vision before. He believes the central figure in the vision to be a hero of the Calamity and recounts the old stories of Bazzoxan's origin:

"The Kryn capital of Rosohna was the Betrayer Gods' citadel of Ghor Dranas in the time before the Calamity, and the Betrayers' Rise was once a fortress protecting Ghor Dranas. In the darkest days of the Calamity, the Prime Deities and their most loyal champions laid siege to Ghor Dranas before capturing the Betrayers' Rise and routing the Betrayer Gods' forces there. Though storytellers have long since forgotten the names of many of those heroes, the force of their bonds still resonates across the land."

If the characters ask him to elaborate, Foghome draws their attention to several alcoves where the plants are markedly healthier than the rest of those within the temple. Engraved on the back walls of the alcoves are the following timeworn words in Common (parts of the messages that are no longer legible are indicated by dashes):

items: "Friends forever. Don't——forget——"
"You owe me a drink in Marquet, A——"
"I am writing this——record of me stating——I will never, ever duel you again."
"This——written proof——promise to show you the mountains of my home one day."
"We love you. We will always be with you."

entries.name: B6: Wall of the Unforgotten

entries: A stretch of stone wall is carved with names and wreathed in dried flowers, silver necklaces, and ropes weighted with good-luck charms. The ground near the wall is cluttered with trinkets left there as offerings. A drow of the Aurora Watch prays near a corner of the wall.
The Wall of the Unforgotten is a memorial site for the soldiers of the Aurora Watch. The wall is crowded with names, most scratched into the surface with knives.

The praying figure is a lawful neutral, drow {@creature priest} of the Luxon named Kalym Telaarin. Kalym is 300 years old and has many scars on his otherwise handsome face. His left leg from the knee down is an intricate prosthetic carved from chitinous black rock and ringed with bands of pale purple light. As the characters approach, Kalym rises to his feet and says sternly, "Be respectful. They've earned their rest, and they deserve to have that rest honored."

If the characters show Kalym the carving they received from the young drow in the infirmary ({@area area B3|0fe|x}), his demeanor softens. He explains that it's part of a recent practice taken up by younger members of the Aurora Watch: when a soldier is not sure of living long enough to make friends that will hold a memorial for them, they arrange to have a keepsake of theirs placed by the wall in their honor.

Kalym directs the characters to place the scout's carving amid the items strewn at the base of the wall. After the characters do this, Kalym kneels and resumes praying. If the characters stay until he is done a couple minutes later, Kalym rises and gifts each willing character with a magical Mote of Possibility, which manifests as a flash of silver light as he touches each character's forehead in turn. A character who fails a saving throw or misses on an attack roll can use a reaction to expend their Mote of Possibility, allowing them to reroll the {@dice d20}. The character must use the new roll. A Mote of Possibility vanishes from a character after 24 hours or when it is expended.

Kalym returns to duty after imparting his gifts. He has no useful information about the Betrayers' Rise, the {@item Jewel of Three Prayers|CRCotN}, or the comings and goings of faction agents in Bazzoxan.

entries.name: B7: The Ready Room
entries: The Ready Room is Bazzoxan's only inn and one of the only structures in town that doesn't look like a military barracks:

A large barn with a steeply pointed roof looms over the battered structures near the center of town. Over the double door hangs a sign that bears the tavern's name, The Ready Room, in Undercommon, Orc, Goblin, and Common.

The Ready Room is run by Delez and Prima Demona, a brother-and-sister team who are both lawful neutral {@creature drow}. Delez runs the bar and the kitchen and handles most interactions with customers, while Prima manages the finances and inventory.

The ground floor contains piles of tools (lanterns, shovels, ladders, and the like) and a dozen wooden stalls that have been turned into curtained sleeping quarters, each one holding five wooden cots. A rope-and-pulley hoist functions like an elevator, allowing access to a spacious loft where the proprietors have equipped a bar and surrounded it with two dozen stools that are mostly occupied by patrons whenever the place is open for business. Behind the bar is a cooking space with a stove, where Derez prepares food for guests. A curtain behind the bar conceals a small office and storage room, where Prima spends much of her time.

A tankard of beer costs 1 cp, while a bowl of mushy rice and overcooked fish costs 2 cp. The use of a cot costs 2 sp per night. Characters can purchase any common adventuring equipment at the Ready Room, but all such items sell for double their normal price. Although Prima doesn't appreciate her prices being questioned, a character who makes a successful DC 17 Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) check can get her to lower the prices to only a 50 percent markup.

entries.name: Rivals
entries: The rivals like to gather for food and drinks at the bar. This is a good place for the characters to sit and chat with them, especially if the two groups didn't interact much in {@adventure chapter 2|CRCotN|2}. It's also a chance to show how the rivals' travels have begun to weigh on them; there is a different quality to the tone of their boasts, as well as the way they address each other and the characters (see "{@area Rivals in Bazzoxan|0f1|x}" earlier in the chapter).

entries.name: Question and Answers
entries: Question, a chaotic neutral, tiefling {@creature monastic operative|CRCotN} (see {@adventure appendix A|CRCotN|8}), can be found lounging around the Ready Room at all hours. Unlike most others in Bazzoxan, Question almost always has a smile on her face.

The tiefling doesn't take notice of the characters unless they make contact first, at which point she performs an awkward little bow. After introducing herself, Question launches into an excited spiel:

"Tell me you feel it, too," says the tiefling with a grin. "My comrades don't, but I do. The history surrounding this place. The romance of heroes fighting against impossible odds, sacrificing everything for the sake of defending the world. All done for people who would never know them, never think of them, never be able to thank them. Simply because it was the right thing to do. And ages later, we now see the Aurora Watch somehow doing the same. And they don't even know it!"

Question calls this phenomenon, related to the cyclical nature of history, "mythic resonance." She believes that acts of monumental courage leave an impression on the world that lingers after all memory of the deeds has faded. Question theorizes that this has occurred in Bazzoxan, and the ancient battles of the Calamity are still echoing here today.

entries.name: What Question Knows
entries: Question is eager to show characters her sketchbook. She explains that her drawings are based on research she conducted in the archives of the Cobalt Soul in Ank'Harel, the city where she has lived for the past five years. On the pages of the sketchbook, characters can see the following drawings:

items: A sketch of an island bathed in the moonlight of Catha and Ruidus, both full. The island is covered with trees, marble pillars, and crystal shards and resembles the final chamber in the Emerald Grotto.
A rough drawing of what appears to be a more elaborate version of the {@item Jewel of Three Prayers|CRCotN}. It is larger and has three delicate spires inlaid with stones.

A rubbing of a symbol that depicts a long-haired woman peering into the distance. A character who makes a successful DC 12 Intelligence ({@skill Religion}) check identifies this as the holy symbol of Avandra the Change Bringer. Question explains that this rubbing was taken from a wall carving in the Betrayers' Rise (see {@area area R1|129|x} later in the chapter).

A folk ballad, written in Undercommon, that speaks of an unnamed "halfway god," a champion who was given so much power by three of the Prime Deities during the Calamity that he became nearly divine himself.

entries.name: Question and the Jewel
entries: If asked about the {@item Jewel of Three Prayers|CRCotN}, Question speaks of it with reverent awe, calling it a "lost Vestige." Though she doesn't know the relic's true nature, she believes the jewel was an ordinary amulet until it was filled with divine power during the Calamity.

If the characters show Question the jewel, the tiefling quivers with excitement and immediately requests a closer look. After a minute of inspection, she says that this object is the key to the mythic cycle that resonates throughout Bazzoxan. She begs the characters to contact her again if they learn more about the jewel during their stay in Bazzoxan.

entries.name: Question's Allies
entries: Question doesn't have much to say about the other members of her expedition, dismissing them as the sort who prefer excitement over introspection. A character who succeeds on a DC 11 Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) check discerns that Question is hiding something; if confronted, she admits that she is terrified of going inside the Betrayers' Rise. She explains that after entering the temple with the other expedition members, she heard voices calling to her, which nearly caused her to run away screaming. Instead, she feigned sudden illness and returned to town after promising to make the next trip inside. She expresses concern that her compatriots have yet to return, but she holds out hope that they'll make it back out.

entries.name: Aloysia Telfan
entries: During their conversation with Question, characters who have a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 12 or higher notice a gaunt figure in scarlet robes nearby, eavesdropping. This figure, {@creature Aloysia Telfan|CRCotN}, is a lawful evil, elf {@creature occult initiate|CRCotN} (see {@adventure appendix A|CRCotN|8}) who thirsts for knowledge and power. She approaches the characters, if they don't accost her first, and greets them politely.

Aloysia gets right to the point: she wants to find an ancient prayer site deep inside the Betrayers' Rise—and based on what she has learned of the characters from their conversation with Question, she surmises that such a mission would be beneficial to them as well. She offers to pay the characters 50 gp each to accompany her, though they can get her up to 100 gp each with a successful DC 13 Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) check if they haggle. If pressed to reveal what she's after, Aloysia explains that she's looking for a crimson mineral called ruidium that is said to be infused with the power of Ruidus. She says nothing about her organization, the Consortium of the Vermilion Dream, unless someone asks about it by name. In that case, she says that the Consortium is a group of folklore aficionados.

entries.name: What Aloysia Knows
entries: Aloysia believes the following facts to be true:

items: Fragmented historical records tell of an unidentified hero of the Calamity who hailed from the lands of Wildemount. He was born under the full moon of Ruidus and wields the vermilion moon's power. (Partially true. Alyxian was marked by Ruidus, but he creates ruidium on his own, not by drawing on the moon's power.)
This hero participated in climactic battles across the continents of Wildemount and Marquet—including the battle at the Betrayers' Rise. (True.)

The hero died in the battle at the Betrayers' Rise and was brought back to life as a vengeful revenant by Avandra the Change Bringer. (Mostly false. Alyxian nearly died but was healed and granted further power by Avandra.)

The hero wore a pendant that contained the power of three gods. This pendant is the key to acquiring the ruidium her organization seeks. (Partially true. The {@item Jewel of Three Prayers|CRCotN} holds the power of three gods and, in its Exalted State, can be used to open the rift to the Netherdeep in Cael Morrow, as described in {@adventure chapter 5|CRCotN|5}.)

entries.name: Roleplaying Aloysia
entries: Assuming the characters are cordial, the ambitious occultist steers the conversation to her interests at every turn, while maintaining a pleasant demeanor and answering just enough of the characters' questions to keep them from walking away.

If the characters turn down her offer, Aloysia's charm vanishes immediately, replaced by cold disdain. Additionally, if any character mentions having received a vision from the Apotheon or reveals that the characters possess the {@item Jewel of Three Prayers|CRCotN}, Aloysia becomes fixated on obtaining the jewel for her faction.

entries.name: Betrayers' Rise
entries: Any time while in Bazzoxan, the characters can choose to travel north to the Betrayers' Rise, which looms over Bazzoxan.

A steep, winding staircase, wide enough for four Medium creatures to walk abreast, leads to a large gate built into the facade of the Betrayers' Rise. Read or paraphrase the following when the characters come close enough to see the details of the structure:

The Betrayers' Rise is both ominous and beautiful. Its black walls are carved with intricate reliefs, many of them depicting scenes of torture. Lifelike grotesques of leering demons perch high above, peering down at you with contempt.
An immense double door forms the entrance. This gate is made of onyx inlaid with copper and silver. Guards of the Aurora Watch stand between you and the demonic fortress.

The Betrayer Gods used demons to defend this fortress-temple against the Prime Deities. The scenes depicted on the fortress walls depict the Prime Deities being tormented. The outer doors are extremely heavy but well balanced and require a combined Strength of 44 to open or close.

The Aurora Watch has {@dice 2d6} {@creature Veteran||veterans} (drow, humans, and orcs) stationed outside the Betrayers' Rise at any time. These guards ensure that the doors remain closed to prevent demons and other evil creatures from escaping. At least one character must succeed on a DC 15 Charisma ({@skill Deception}, {@skill Intimidation}, or {@skill Persuasion}) check before the guards will allow one or more characters to get within 30 feet of the outer doors.

entries.name: Gloomstalker Escape
entries: As the characters examine the Betrayers' Rise and its entrance more closely, read:

Shouting erupts from the soldiers just as the colossal doors fly open. Two shadowy, winged creatures burst through the opening, immediately take flight, and screech as they dive toward you, their ebon talons extended.

The escaped creatures are two {@creature Gloomstalker|EGW|gloomstalkers} (see {@adventure appendix A|CRCotN|8}). The soldiers stationed outside can assist the characters in battling the gloomstalkers, or you can have them rush inside to help three gravely injured Aurora Watch soldiers (lawful good, orc {@creature Knight||knights}) in {@area area R1|129|x}.

Each gloomstalker fights until it is reduced to half its hit points or fewer, then soars away. After seeing the characters in combat against the gloomstalkers, the Aurora Watch soldiers hold the party in high regard. From now on, the characters can freely enter the Betrayers' Rise whenever they like—including right away, if they so desire. After the characters have either entered the Betrayers' Rise or returned to town, the soldiers tend to their wounded and close the doors.

entries.name: Features of the Betrayers' Rise
entries: The interior of the Betrayers' Rise has the following features:

items.name: Black Stone.
items.entry: Unless otherwise noted, all surfaces in the Betrayers' Rise are made of smooth, shiny black stone. The power that pervades the place prevents the architecture from being affected by magic such as {@spell stone shape}.

items.name: Ceilings.
items.entry: Unless otherwise noted, the vaulted ceilings of the temple's chambers are 50 feet high, and its hallways are 20 feet high.

items.name: Light.
items.entry: The interior of the Betrayers' Rise contains no light sources unless otherwise noted.

items.name: Shifting Halls.
items.entry: The interior of the Betrayers' Rise is different for each group that enters. The chaotic magic of the Abyss warps the configuration to stymie explorers and baffle cartographers. The characters experience a particular version of the temple—the one shown on the Betrayers' Rise map. If Aurora Watch soldiers or the rivals enter, they experience a different configuration.

entries.name: Expanding the Betrayers' Rise
entries: If you want to or need to, you can create new maps for the Betrayers' Rise, new encounters there, and other routes through it. The Betrayers' Rise Encounters table provides some suggestions for unsettling creatures that a group might encounter while delving into these new areas, and you can use the {@book treasure tables|DMG|7|Treasure Tables} in {@book chapter 7|DMG|-1} of the {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|DMG} to generate treasure guarded by these creatures.

entries.caption: Betrayers' Rise Encounters
rows: The characters enter a room lined with flickering candles, only to discover that their shadows have detached from them and transformed into {@creature Shadow Demon||shadow demons} (one per character).
Four {@creature Ochre Jelly||ochre jellies} burble along the walls of a hallway, looking for prey to devour.
A {@creature yochlol} in giant spider form skitters around in an antechamber draped in spider webs.
A {@creature yochlol} in drow form wears the insectile armor of the Aurora Watch. Claiming to be a lost Aurora Watch soldier, the demon tries to lure the characters into greater danger.
Two {@condition invisible} {@creature Barlgura||barlguras} ambush the characters.
A passageway opens into what was once a coliseum and now contains three enraged {@creature Nightmare||nightmares}.
A gurgling, acidic river cuts through a cavern where three {@creature Roper||ropers} stealthily await.
Three {@creature Chasme||chasmes} emerge from their hive, which has overtaken what was once a chandelier.
A {@creature glabrezu} tempts all who come into its chamber with promises of riches. Anyone it can't bribe into serving it is attacked.

Orange light emanates from the depths of a chasm, where a {@creature balor} sleeps in molten lava. If it is attacked, the demon wakes. The characters, who have no chance of defeating this powerful demon in combat, must flee or die.

entries.name: Retreat and Reinforcements
entries: To survive the trials of the Betrayers' Rise, the characters might need to retreat to Bazzoxan to regroup and rest. If the characters retreat from the Betrayers' Rise, new demons emerge from the Abyssal portals in the depths of the temple after 8 hours to populate empty areas. Roll a {@dice d6} for each area in the Betrayers' Rise that the characters explored on their previous trip. On a roll of 6, the area has become home to one or more new creatures, determined by rolling another {@dice d6} and consulting the Betrayers' Rise Reinforcements table.

entries.caption: Betrayers' Rise Reinforcements
rows: {@dice 1d6} {@creature Quasit||quasits} nesting in the corpses of the area's previous inhabitants or crawling on the walls in centipede form
{@dice 1d4} {@creature Shadow Demon||shadow demons} lurking in the darkness
{@dice 3d6} {@creature manes} looking for a more powerful demon to lead them
1 {@creature gloomstalker|EGW} (see {@adventure appendix A|CRCotN|8}) feeding on the corpse of a giant rat and hungry for more food

entries.name: Locations in the Betrayers' Rise (R1-R8)
entries: The following locations are keyed to the Betrayers' Rise map.

entries.name: R1: Entrance
entries: When the characters enter the Betrayers' Rise, read:

You stand on a bloodstained bridge that extends over a chasm of swirling silver mist. On the far side of the bridge is a closed double door of black stone inscribed with a circle containing the profile of a smiling woman. The symbol is gouged with deep marks, as if something with claws has tried, but failed, to scour it from the stone.

A character who succeeds on a DC 10 Intelligence ({@skill Religion}) check recognizes the engraving as the symbol of Avandra the Change Bringer. If the characters have the {@item Jewel of Three Prayers|CRCotN}, add:

This double door begins to radiate faint crimson light. The light slowly pulses, as if beckoning you to touch it. The {@i Jewel of Three Prayers} grows warm to the touch and pulses in sync with the glowing door.

The characters can't pass through the double door leading to area R2 unless they have the {@item Jewel of Three Prayers|CRCotN}. The doors glow whenever the jewel comes within 20 feet of them. While the doors glow, they can be opened with a gentle touch; they can't be opened by any other method. If the characters don't have the jewel, they must turn back and try to acquire it from their rivals, or they can descend into the misty chasm beneath them (see "Misty Chasm" below) if they have the means to do so safely.

entries.name: Outer Doors
entries: The Aurora Watch won't allow the outer doors to remain open. If the characters want to leave the Betrayers' Rise after the outer doors are closed, they must open the doors themselves.

entries.name: Misty Chasm
entries: Beneath the bridge is an 80-foot-long vertical shaft that opens into a 1,000-foot-deep chasm (see {@area area R15|160|x}) shrouded in silvery mist. Any character who listens intently hears hissing voices emanating from inside the chasm. The voices say the following in Common:
"Together. Yes, we can break them together. Come to us. Let us catch you. Let us have you. Come to us. We won't let you fall."
The shaft leading down to the chasm is too sheer to climb without the use of magic or climbing gear. Any character who falls into the chasm takes 70 ({@dice 20d6}) bludgeoning damage from the plunge.

entries.name: R2: Hall of Holes

entries: The walls of this hallway are covered with carvings that depict a great battle involving mortals, celestials, and fiends. A faint whistling noise emerges from the walls, sounding almost like snoring.

A character who succeeds on a DC 15 Intelligence ({@skill History}) check recognizes that the wall carvings depict the Battle of the Barbed Fields. This fight was a climactic battle of the Calamity, in which the devotees of the Prime Deities broke through the garrison at the Betrayers' Rise and reached the walls of Ghor Dranas. Prominently depicted in one scene is a proud, melancholy warrior with curly hair and carrying a spear and shield. By his side are two figures; a white-haired girl no more than twelve years old, and a young adult woman with hair that flows behind her, turning into a road upon which countless soldiers march. A character who makes a successful DC 10 Intelligence ({@skill Religion}) check realizes that the latter two figures are common depictions of the gods Sehanine the Moon Weaver and Avandra the Change Bringer.

No check is needed to identify the source of the snoring sound: it comes from the walls. Close examination reveals that the walls have scores of 1-inch-diameter holes drilled into them. As the characters move along the corridor, eyeballs, teeth, and liquid flesh begin to ooze from the holes, pooling on the floor. After 1 round, this grotesque slurry forms into three {@creature Gibbering Mouther||gibbering mouthers} that attack the characters. One mouther appears at each end of the hall, and the third appears in the middle of the hallway to the west.

entries.name: Escape Route
entries: The double door leading to area R1 closes behind the characters unless it is held or wedged open. It glows red when the {@item Jewel of Three Prayers|CRCotN} is within 20 feet of it. While the double door is glowing, it opens with a touch; otherwise, it can't be opened.

entries.name: R3: Vestibule

entries: This chamber is empty except for a skull-shaped vase on a small, semicircular table resting against the back wall of an alcove in the north wall. Six narrower alcoves line the east and west walls. The northeast alcove seems to have once led to a hallway, but it has caved in.

A character can clear the rubble blocking the northeast hallway in 1 hour; reduce the time proportionately if other characters assist. If the rubble is cleared, characters can follow the tunnel beyond it that leads to {@area area R8|143|x}.

entries.name: Northwest Alcove
entries: On the back wall of this alcove is scrawled the following message in Abyssal: "To me, touch your hand. To me, relinquish hope. To you, accept death. To you, invite hollowness." A character who places their hand on this wall feels it writhe beneath their touch. If the character succeeds on a DC 13 Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) check, they understand that the wall seems to want to devour their body, but that the wall can consume only someone who has accepted that they'll die and doesn't struggle against that fate.

While touching the wall, a character can make a DC 15 Wisdom check to make peace with their own death. On a failed check, nothing happens, and the character must rest for at least 1 hour before they can attempt the check again. On a successful check, the wall churns and pulls the character through it, whereupon the character emerges in a narrow hallway (the southern part of area R4). Anyone or anything that character is holding is also pulled through the wall.
A character who succeeds on the check gains the following benefit and drawback:

items.name: Benefit.
items.entry: The character has advantage on saving throws against being {@condition frightened} for the next 24 hours.

items.name: Drawback.
items.entry: The character has disadvantage on death saving throws for the next 24 hours.

entries.name: Secrets of the Skull
entries: The skull vase and the table in the north alcove are the keys to revealing the hidden entrance to the Basilica of Revelry ({@area area R9|149|x}). Close examination reveals that the vase contains the withered remains of a bouquet of lilies.

A character who has a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 13 or higher notices jagged markings along the edge of the table, which make up the following phrase in Abyssal: "Cast that which you value into Oblivion." A character who can read the writing and succeeds on a DC 13 Intelligence ({@skill Religion}) check recognizes that "Oblivion" refers to Tharizdun, the Betrayer God of emptiness and entropy, also known as the Chained Oblivion.

To open the entrance, a character must place something of value inside the vase, such as a bouquet of fresh flowers, a gemstone, coins totaling at least 25 gp, or anything else the character regards as valuable. Once a satisfactory offering has been placed within the skull-shaped vase, its eye sockets flash red, the offering decays to the point of being worthless, and the wall behind the table slides upward, revealing a long tunnel that eventually leads down to {@area area R12|152|x}.

entries.name: R4: Path of Emptiness
entries: Characters are {@condition deafened} while in this corridor. The only sound any of them can hear is the beating of their own heart.

entries.name: One-Way Secret Door
entries: The wall that lies between area R4 and {@area area R3|132|x} is a featureless surface when viewed from this side, offering no way of returning to area R3. This one-way passage can't be navigated, except with a {@spell passwall} spell or similar magic.

entries.name: R5: Flagellant's Path

entries: You enter a chamber that reeks of death and incense. To the west is an open archway that leads into a small side room, and to the north is a hallway flanked by two statues of swollen, worm-bodied abominations, each with three arms and the hairless head of a howling, fang-toothed man wearing a crown of black spikes.
The hallway past the statues is lined with dozens of curved, quivering blades and ends at a double door. Mounted above the double doors is an eight-inch-tall canister made of translucent crystal.

A character who succeeds on a DC 13 Intelligence ({@skill Religion}) check recognizes the statues as depictions of Torog the Crawling King, god of enslavement and torture. Characters who have a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 12 or higher notice a phrase written in Undercommon on the floor between the two statues that reads: "Revel in the pain you inflict on others. Relish the pain you suffer yourself as an offering to the Crawling King."

entries.name: Bladed Corridor
entries: The corridor north of the statues has twitching silver blades protruding from its walls. Whenever one or more creatures are in the hall, the floor tilts to one side and then the other so that creatures stumble into the blades. A creature that moves into the corridor or starts its turn there must make a DC 20 Dexterity saving throw, taking 17 ({@dice 5d6}) slashing damage on a failed saving throw, or half as much damage on a successful one.
The first time a character takes damage from the blades, read or paraphrase the following:
A dim burgundy glow suffuses the corridor, illuminating every razor-sharp bit of metal as dark fluid begins to pour into the canister above the double door.

entries.name: Opening the Double Door
entries: The double door at the north end of the corridor can be opened only after the crystal canister is filled with blood or demonic ichor. To meet this requirement, the bladed walls must deal a total of 70 slashing damage to creatures that have blood or demonic ichor in their bodies. A character within reach of the canister can pour blood into it; each ounce of blood poured into the canister reduces by 5 the amount of damage needed to open the doors.
If the crystal canister is destroyed, the characters have no way to disable the hall's trap. The canister is a Tiny object with AC 13, 5 hit points, and immunity to poison and psychic damage.

entries.name: Trap Reset
entries: The corridor stops tilting and resets itself after 1 hour or when the double door is opened, whereupon all blood in the crystal canister disappears.

entries.name: R6: Cloister of Penitence
entries: Opening the door to this room releases three hostile {@creature Flameskull||flameskulls}—the remains of torturers who served the Betrayer Gods long ago.

entries.title: Torturers who served the Betrayer Gods linger on as flameskulls

entries: The floor of this small room is crusted with dried blood, and the walls are lined with hooks, spiked whips, and other implements of torture or self-flagellation. Slouched in a corner is a desiccated human body in acolyte's robes.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: A character who searches the corpse finds a pouch containing 22 gp and four stoppered vials that each contain 1 ounce of blood. This blood can be poured into the canister at the north end of the Flagellant's Path (see {@area area R5|139|x} for details).

entries.name: R7: Stairs Down
entries: Five-foot-wide stairs of black stone cling to the walls of a rectangular shaft. The stairs descend 100 feet to {@area area R11|151|x}.
As the characters make their descent, the sound of distant wailing (emanating from the statue in {@area area R12|152|x}) grows louder.

entries.name: R8: Spiders' Chancel

entries: A haunting song echoes through this half-collapsed chamber, interspersed with a clicking sound that seems to reverberate in your bones. Thick spiderwebs, giving off a pale green glow, stretch from floor to ceiling. Crawling in the webs are two giant spiders and two creatures that look like drow but with the lower bodies of monstrous spiders. Four corpses cocooned in webs rest atop the debris near the west wall.

The two {@creature Drider||driders} are former drow warriors of the Aurora Watch mutated by the demonic magic of Lolth the Spider Queen. The two {@creature Giant Spider||giant spiders} in this area have also been tainted, changing their type to Fiend.
The driders and the giant spiders attack intruders on sight, pursuing those that flee.

entries.name: Hidden Singers
entries: A {@spell see invisibility} spell or similar magic reveals a mural composed of ghostly figures on the walls of the chamber. The figures all have their mouths open as though singing or screaming. One figure in the middle of the north wall holds a large book that glows faintly and is warm to the touch. Pressing on the book in the mural opens a secret door in the northeast corner of the room, which can also be found by examining that section of wall and succeeding on a DC 20 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check. Beyond the secret door is a small room lined with moldering, leather-bound books. Each tome contains barely legible scrawlings in Abyssal written by an unsteady hand, detailing the demon lords' alliances with the Betrayer Gods during the Calamity.

A character who spends 10 minutes searching the small chamber finds a book buried in the debris, opened to a page that shows a drawing of a stained-glass window. Written beneath the drawing is the following mantra:

"First praise be to the Spider Queen, whose kingdom was forsaken. Next, exult the Ruiner, whose spear shook the green earth. In turn, pay homage to Oblivion and the ending of all things. And last, I give myself to the Crawling King."

A character who can read the writing and succeeds on a DC 15 Intelligence check realizes that this is a code or instruction. (It provides the correct sequence of sigils to touch to open the stained-glass mural in area R9.)

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The corpses are the remains of an Aurora Watch expedition that was trapped in the Betrayers' Rise. A character who searches the bodies finds an onyx-hilted longsword that has become a {@item Longsword of Vengeance||sword of vengeance} haunted by the spirit of its former wielder.

entries.name: R9: Basilica of Revelry

entries: Two rows of black stone pillars marbled with white veins support the vaulted ceiling of this hall, the floor of which is polished to a mirror-like sheen. Ornate brass braziers rest at the feet of four of the pillars, and faint music fills the hall.
The music has no readily identifiable source, and the four braziers are bolted to the floor. If one or more characters enter the room, read:

The four braziers ignite, their bowls filling with pale flames that coalesce into dancing, humanoid forms. The glow from the flames glints off the north wall, where a towering mosaic of stained glass depicts a maelstrom of color, within which are nine symbols. The image shifts even as you stare at it.
Each {@creature dancing flame|CRCotN} uses the {@creature succubus}/{@creature incubus} stat block, with these changes:

entries.title: This stained-glass mosaic is the key to escaping the Basilica of Revelry

items: The flame sheds bright light in a 20-foot radius and dim light for an additional 20 feet. If it leaves the hall or is reduced to 0 hit points, it is destroyed and can't re-form for 24 hours.
It lacks the Shapechanger trait and the Etherealness action.
Its Claw attack deals fire damage instead of slashing damage.

entries: The dancing flames appear to beckon to characters who are closest to them. A character who succeeds on a DC 12 Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) check intuits, based on the way they move in time with the music, that the flames are looking for dance partners.

A character who uses an action to dance within 5 feet of a flame creature can make a DC 12 Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics}) or Charisma ({@skill Performance}) check. On a successful check, the dancing flame flickers brightly with joy and uses its reaction to fly to the stained-glass mosaic and touch the next symbol in the sequence needed to open it (see "Stained-Glass Mosaic" below). On a failed check, or if a character approaches within 5 feet of a flame but refuses to dance, the flame attacks.

entries.name: Stained-Glass Mosaic
entries: The 10-foot-wide section of wall at the north end of the basilica resembles a tall, stained-glass window. Its imagery changes constantly, like the patterns in a kaleidoscope, but the nine symbols remain static. A character who succeeds on a DC 11 Intelligence ({@skill Religion}) check recognizes these as the symbols of evil gods. The symbols and the gods they represent are summarized in the Symbols of the Gods table.

If four of the symbols are pressed in the correct order, as noted in the Symbol Sequence table, a door opens at the base of the wall, leading to a hallway ({@area area R10|14d|x}). A creature that presses an incorrect symbol must make a DC 16 Wisdom saving throw, taking 28 ({@dice 8d6}) psychic damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

The stained-glass mosaic can be bypassed by breaking through it with a successful DC 12 Strength check or by destroying it. The mosaic has AC 11, 10 hit points, vulnerability to bludgeoning and thunder damage, and immunity to poison and psychic damage. Destroying the mosaic causes the flame creatures in the hall to attack. Moreover, each creature in the hall when the mosaic breaks must make a DC 20 Wisdom saving throw unless it is a Construct, a Fiend, or an Undead. On a failed save, the creature is cursed and can't regain hit points until the effect on that creature is ended by a {@spell remove curse} spell or similar magic.
If destroyed, the stained-glass window repairs itself after 1 hour.

entries.caption: Symbols of the Gods
rows: Severed Hand with an Eye in the Palm

entries.name: R10: Supplicant's Pit

entries: The walls of this hallway are decorated with carvings of supine figures and chained bodies. The floor is covered by a nest of black chains.
The sound of distant wailing comes from a dark, circular hole in the floor at the north end of the hall.

A creature that enters this hall immediately feels weighed down and senses a terrible dread clawing at the back of its mind. The creature must make a DC 14 Wisdom saving throw and succeeds automatically if it is immune to the {@condition charmed} or {@condition frightened} condition. On a failed save, the creature falls {@condition prone} and its speed is reduced to 0 as it is forced to grovel before an unseen presence. The creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. Once a creature succeeds on the saving throw, it gains immunity to this effect for the next 24 hours.

entries.name: Chains of Darkness
entries: When a creature falls {@condition prone} in this hall, the chains on the floor slither toward it, and the figures carved in the walls drone in low voices, "Imprison those who cannot resist you. Drag all life into darkness." The creature must succeed on a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw or be {@condition grappled} by the chains (escape DC 15). Until it escapes, the creature takes 5 ({@dice 1d10}) psychic damage at the start of each of its turns. Any creature that is not {@condition grappled} by the chains can use an action to try to free a chained creature within reach, doing so with a successful DC 15 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check. Whatever the result of the check, the creature making the attempt takes 11 ({@dice 2d10}) psychic damage.

entries.name: Circular Hole
entries: The circular hole at the north end of the hall is the mouth of a shaft that descends 10 feet before opening in the ceiling of area R12. The distance from the floor of this hallway to the floor of area R12 is 100 feet. A character who falls down the hole can try to catch the outstretched hand of the northernmost stone arm in area R12, doing so with a successful DC 15 Dexterity saving throw and reducing the fall from 100 feet to 30 feet. The character can climb down the rest of the way with a successful DC 15 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check.

entries.name: R11: Stairs Up
entries: Five-foot-wide stairs of black stone cling to the walls of a rectangular shaft. The stairs ascend 100 feet to {@area area R7|142|x}.
From this area, the wailing in R12 is loud and impossible to ignore.

entries.name: R12: Threshold of the Excoriated

entries: The awful wailing noise gets even louder as you approach this chamber. A beam of light from above illuminates a statue in the middle of the room. The statue, made of pale marble, is shaped like a man on his knees, arms pinioned behind his back, trussed up in chains that cut into his skin. Hooks line the corners of the figure's mouth, pulling his lips away from his teeth, and smaller barbs encircle his eyes, holding the eyelids open. All the while, hideous noise comes out of the statue's open mouth—yet still, its expression is one of ecstasy. A double door made of iron is set into the statue's chest; these surfaces have no handles.
A triangle, each side forty feet long, is carved into the floor around the statue, surrounding it. At each of the triangle's points, a stone arm juts up from the floor with its hand outstretched.

A {@spell detect magic} spell reveals an aura of abjuration magic emanating from the iron doors in the statue's chest. Similar auras are apparent in the palms of the stone arms that are within the spell's range.

entries.name: Wailing Statue
entries: Any creature within 30 feet of the statue that can hear the wailing sound coming from it must make a successful DC 16 Charisma saving throw or become cursed by Torog's hunger. A creature that succeeds on this saving throw is immune to the effect of the wailing statue for 24 hours. The curse has the following effects on a creature:
